thread.title_full: Clinton Township trustee, who can’t run, hopes sister saves her seat | The Columbus Dispatch

author: The Columbus Dispatch
title: Clinton Township trustee, who can’t run, hopes sister saves her seat
text:
Jane Cera was out knocking on doors last week, asking for votes for a Clinton Township trustee seat, when she came upon a woman who took her flier and folded it dismissively.
“I’m voting for Paula,” the woman said.
“I said, ‘Paula’s not running, ma’am,’  ” Cera said.
Both statements, it would turn out, were true.
Paula Armentrout, a current trustee in the township of 4,100 people in the north-central part of Franklin County, isn’t on the November ballot. She made a paperwork error that foiled her bid for re-election and disqualified her from running as a write-in .
That mistake left the seat wide open.
Three write-in candidates quickly jumped into the void: Cera, Roger Gilkerson and Robin L. Bush. Bush is Armentrout’s sister.
Cera recounted her experience on the campaign trail to The Dispatch on Monday. On Tuesday morning, Armentrout told a reporter that the notion that her sister was running as essentially a placeholder was “ridiculous.”
“I’m running her to get her elected because she shares my philosophies,” Armentrout said.
But later that morning, Armentrout called back.
“You’ve given me an idea,” she said. “I’m thinking, yeah, that’s what I’m going to do.”
That idea is that Bush could win election and then step down, leaving the township’s two remaining trustees to fill the seat. Armentrout’s hope is that they pick her.
Neither Carl Reardon nor John Coneglio, the other trustees, returned calls or emails seeking comment.
“Hey, if it can be done ... I have unfinished business there,” Armentrout said.
Cera said she thinks Armentrout’s plan was in place long before Tuesday, “or I wouldn’t have had this voter suggest it to me in the manner that she did.”
But she said that if the maneuver is legal, which it appears to be — neither the Franklin County Board of Elections nor the Ohio secretary of state’s office had an opinion on it — it’s fair.
Even if some people don’t like it.
“The voters that I’m talking to are not that amused by that scenario,” Cera said. “It feels a little off to them.”
